noun.description: A thing that is or may be chosen.
examples: choose the cheapest options for supplying energy

noun.description: An offensive play in which the ball carrier has the option to run, pass, hand off, or lateral.

verb.description: Buy or sell an option on (something)
examples: his second script will have been optioned by the time you read this

phrases: Maybe if you were in a different profession you could, so you leave your options open, which is what I do.
Nothing's cast in stone and we're keeping our options open.
If, like me, you're looking for that special someone, it's always good to keep your options open.
They were keeping their options open and the long term plan would be to provide a library adjoining the College House property.
I think both have left their options open, but neither knows what to do.
origin: Mid 16th century: from French, or from Latin optio(n-), from the stem of optare choose. The verb dates from the 1930s.
